a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:28): He suggests we version the spec, when what he really argues for is versioning pages to a IE version
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:29): and his suggestion to upgrade that to <!DOCTYPE html6>, <!DOCTYPE html7> and into infinity totally misses the point of Don't Break the Web
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:29): There have been several suggestions like <meta ie-version-support="7"> already, which should suit his needs just fine
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:29): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, those suggestions are equally silly
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:30): I can see how spec versioning would be convenient for his IE versioning plan, but that doesn't seem like a sufficient justification in itself for versioning
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:30): But they at the very least attempt to solve the right problem
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:30): I'll have to read the replies and think about it
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:30): must we be doomed to repeat the mistakes of browser sniffing?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:31): his example of the child selector html>body breaking the web when they implemented it is based on the fact that they fixed the filter, but failed to fix the significant limitations that relied on it
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:31): the same applies to * html

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:35): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: authors shouldn't rely on one bug in order to fix another, as it might break in browser upgrades. but they do. ms cannot fix all bugs at the same time. it is problematic but it's not a reason to introduce another rendering mode
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:35): the real problem is that microsoft stopped developing ie for a few years
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:36): They're willing to ship bugs, but not fixes. A cruel process for us all.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:37): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, they didn't even fix all the major well documented limitations, which is the problem...

39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:38): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9:  <meta ie-version-support="7"> does not solve the problem. This problem is not IE-centric. Mozilla, Opera and Safari have bugs. All of them have or will have a "big bug" that will break the web if corrected. They will have to define a similar mecanism for opt-in (they all have already done it one time with doctype switching, they will do many time more in the future).
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:38): We shouldn't have a proprietary ie-specific mecanism
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:38): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: Mozilla, Opera, Safari have all demonstrated will to fix bugs

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:38): they need to completely remove hasLayout from their standards mode, it's nonsense.  They need to fix the bugs that made use of: * html  { height: 1%; }, which they didn't (yet they fixed * html)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:39): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: the other browser vendors don't want to introduce new rendering modes
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:40): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, what they will do if some correction breaks the web (and not only a dozen of pages) ?
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:40): 1- leave that bug ; 2- break the web ; 3- require an opt-in mecanism

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:40): I know you can't always rely on them fixing both bugs (the one that let the filter work and the limitation), but the major, well documented ones should have been fixed
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:40): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, well change the spec is possible if all have the same bugs
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:41): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, if Mozilla has an Opera doesn't, change the spec will introduce the opposite bug in Opera
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:41): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: that's what we're aiming for (if all agree on the same set of bugs, we have interop)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:42): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: content generally doesn't rely on things where all browsers disagree
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:42): if one browser does one thing and another does the opposite, then we standardise that one that is most compatible with the web.

39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:42): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, you're saying that what will be in the future will correspond exactly to what they want (is to say they won't do bug withou willing it)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:42): The whole SGML business showed some browsers are willing to break for fixes, even when they have no benefit whatsoever

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:42): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: representatives from Mozilla, Opera and Apple have all said that we don't want a switch for opt-in to web-breaking standards
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:43): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: so I think you are out on a limb saying we will want such a mechanism in the future
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:43): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: our preference is to fix the spec if something it requires would BTW

39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:43): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884, I understand that, but I don't see what they will do if they are in front of a "oups, we did somehting incompatible and it's used by many authors"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:44): It doesn't get that far
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:44): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: the intended benefit was increased interop. although there was a different way to achieve interop we found out later
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:44): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: most sites basically have one mode for IE and another for Firefox+Opera+Safari
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:44): Relevant intercompatabilities are noticed and reported
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:44): 39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf: since we are already closer to each other, it's less likely for browser-specific bugs to get widely locked in
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:44): you have faith in future, I don't ;)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:44): anyway, most of these web breakage issues come up for CSS and DOM
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:45): using an HTML version to trigger CSS and DOM changes seems like bad layering
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:45): would like to get interop with ie on css and dom, even if that meant changing the css and dom specs
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:45): I have never heard an example of a site depending on a browser-specific *HTML* bug (as opposed to DOM, JS or CSS)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:46): Conditional comments ;)
39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:46): you may be right with this on

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:47): should study the differences between almost standards mode and full standards mode a bit more, then propose to the css wg to spec almost standards mode so full can be dropped
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:47): not saying it hasn't happened, but it seems less common, and I think there are structural reasons why that is so
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (03:48): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I think it would probably be good to have almost standards mode be the standard model
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:49): As long as quirks mode is the default, every new document will be quirks mode if the author doesn't take care...
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:49): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: indeed. new documents will be produced that rely on quirks mode
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:50): today, i think 50% or so doesn't have a doctype at all, and 90% or so use quirks mode
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:51): the rest use almost standards mode with only very few using full standards mode
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:51): according to the studies i've seen anyway
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:52): perhaps css 2.1 should spec what is required for quirks mode too

39446a94055a1d99d64ee4c4112d92bf (03:52): wen I think about it I'm just scared about having multiple proprietary versionning mecanisms which aim specific versions of specific browsers, having to explicitly opt-in a version for each browser, and in consequence to always aim a series of version/brower and never the spec. (I know, I'm pessimist, I had bad experiences with all CSS hacks, doctype switching and conditionnal comments)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:54): The future we're offering contains a single <!DOCTYPE html> and eternal bliss ;)
